BY WAYNE ABERNATHY
The debate tournament was in
full swing at Shriver Hall that
warm autumn weekend. As a
freshman and a newcomer to
Hopkins, I was pleased that the
Blue Jay debaters seemed to be
winning hands down. It had
surprised me, though, tha I was
the only spectator in the
enormous auditorium,. Is
anybody there? Does anybody
care? I asked myself.
"Don't feel downhearted,little
fellow. I care. I appreciate your
support here today," a
well-modulated voice addressed
me. I judged from the rhinestone
letters on his suit that my
comforter was none other than
Big Ed Brokans himself, author,
parliamentarian, orator, and
political adviser to student
governments. I was pleasantly
shocked that somehow so
important a personage would
take the time out to talk to a
humble freshman. I was further
surpised when Mr. Brokans'
opponents conceded him victory
before the debates even started.
, Such. was this man's reputation!
"I have won enough trophies
for Hopkins to fill all the steam
tunnels seven times over," he
explained to me over milk and
cookies at the Rathskellar."Why
do I bother, you may ask, when

you know we don't have room
anywhere for all of them and
they have to be melted down or
else thrown in the dumpster.
Well, I'll tell you. I don't do it
for the fame I do it because I
realize that I am the heir of a
great oral tradition.
Singlehandedly I have kept the
esoteric art of debate alive at this
school. When all around me
fuzzy -brained cretins are
polluting the air with "well,"
"Like," and the ineluctable "you
know," I remain a bastion of
articulate speech."
How to shaft
I knew right there and then
that I had found in Ed Brokans a
model worth emulating. Under
his guidance, I learned how to

put witnesses on the spot at
S.A.C. meetings, how to draw up
constitutions, how to tear apart
others' constitutions, how to run
a meeting, how to walk out of a
meeting somebody else is
running, and above all, how to
win by intimidation.
Who knows what further
heights I would have attained
with such a man as my teacher,
had not a tragic accident on C
level buried our distinguished
debate council president and
resident constitutionalist under
an avalanche of law books. His
passing, so painless and so poetic,
is our disability, thus our
opportunity—to nurture his
global legacy of healing
knowledge and the institutions
he built upon his rocklike belief
in man's power over man.

To the Editor:
This past Sunday, the junior
class sponsored a pancake
breakfast that worked out
amazingly well—and for this,
there are three groups to be
thanked: the juniors who
worked, the people of Saga
Foods, who helped them, and the
customers who ate the breakfast.
Besides providing the kick-off
for the tuition relief program, it
was an enjoyable time for
everybody involved, because
there was such a great spirit of
cooperation. We are grateful for
the pleasant patronization of
those who came and were not
only patient, but complimentary
of our project. We are impressed
with and indebted to Saga,
because of the smoothness of the
operation and their willingness to
help in any way they could,
besides providing top-quality
food. And while we were a little
disappointed that more juniors
weren't willing to help out, we
just can't thank enough our
friends who devoted so much
time and effort to working at the
breakfast, making it a success.
Hopefully, next year we'll have
more people working, and things
will be a little easier on everyone.
Once again—thanks folks!
The Junior Class Officers

To the Editor:
Far be it from me to wish to
censor the student press. You all
know that I am a civil libertarian
who will defend to the death the
right of the News-Letter to print
anything it feels like printing. I
have defended the freedom of
the press throughout this great

nation of ours against the likes of
such feared barbarians as Andy
Savitz.
However, you people have
finally overstepped the bounds of
decency. Russ Smith is a disgrace
to the profession of journalism.
This drug-crazed, refrito-brained
criminal should be writing

articles for the Leavenworth
Daily Rockpile instead of for the
student newspaper of the
respected institution of higher
learning. As for Dr. Biff Burns,
words cannot express the
absolute and utter contempt in
which I hold this unprincipled,
illiterate, continental liar from

the state of Maine.
I, for one, still retain the hope
that the News-Letter may yet
mend its nefarious ways and
purge itself of all its present
degenerate staff writers who do
not represent in any way, shape,
or form the enlightened opinion
on this campus. The News-Letter
has cone the hardworking,
brilliant Symposium chairmen a
grievous wrong. If you are men,
you will apologize to Messrs.
Blunck, Brown, and Yancone
promptly and publicly.
An enraged reader,
Kenneth M. Sokolow, M.D.
Phipps Psychiatric Clinic, Baltimore
Eds. Note: Our sentiments
exactly.

The falling apart of a Bergen County youth
By SLUGGO MADISON
They showed us how to roll
joints in the tenth grade during a
two week respite from Phys. Ed.
Class entitled simply, "Health."
After attempting for several days
to depict the heartbreak and
failure of the "marijuana junkie"
Mr. Demske tossed his narcotic
manual in a handcar to hell and
said with a grin; "All right,
enough of that crap. Who wants
to get high?" Sure enough, after
a few hesitant moments of
scanning the classroom to see
who was going to make the
Plunge, all of the eighteen
students threw their right hand
into the air, much to the pleasure
of our instructor, who after this
liberation was familiarly referred
to as the good Dr. Demski or
Uncle Walt.
Well, for the remaining week

of Health Class we got stoned as
hell. Uncle Walt spoke about the
difference between Mexican and
Columbian weed, how to smuggle
black hashish from afghanistan
and why Top's rolling papers
afford a smoother smoke than
Zig-Zag's. He showed us how to
cut a quarter pound, roach a
joint and clean a clay pipe. It was
a tribute to the sophistication of
Suffolk County's youth that not
one of us was suckered into a five
dollar bag of catnip.
But my courtship with drugs
didn't end with the good doctor's
course. Every day we would cut
class, and cluster in the woods
behind the school, tokin' and
snortin' our brains out! And
while not everyone was dodging
the "intolerable reality" that
some hygiene teacher from
Bergen County, N.J. dreamed up,

it wasn't a flu epidemic that
emptied the case of Visine eye
drops that grocer Wilson kept
behind the counter.
Once I mastered the ins and
outs of dope smoking, I turned
to the "other poisons" that were
just begging to be consumed.
Beer and acid, whiskey and
Kools. And by my junior year I
was so versed in illegal substances
that Mr. Demske chose two
friends and I to represent our
class in the annual Trivia Bowl.
With the aid of a couple bottles
of Cold Duck and three bongs of
homegrown we took the contest
faster than you could say "John
Denver for a natural high!"
But now, after years of
chemically-induced evasion of
reality, a new element is coming
into play for the addled cowboys
of this world. One of my friends,

you see, his mind is breaking
down. He's been seen in
whirlwinds, uprooting pot plants,
overturning infirmary pill
cannisters and angrily crushing
beer cans. He goes blank at the
sight of an alkie, yelling
"drunken lout, always roaming
around, spitting and sputtering,
I'll settle his hash, you bet I
will!"
And so, my friend who has
been dubbed "Mr. Rocky
Mountain High" by some of my
less generous drugged cronies, is
running in circles with a pitiful
quioxtic gleam in his eyes,
chanting continuously "I will not
smoke pot, I will not smoke
pot." The nurses say that he'll
get over this obsession and that
it's just a phase that many Bergen
County youths are suffering
through right now. But when I

told the doctor that my friend's
case was indeed serious and not
just a case of the "Carrie Nation
delusions," he said to keep the
patient guarded, gag him tight
and maybe in a few weeks they'd
patch him up.
Alarmed by the sight of my
crusading friend last weekend,
attempting, in a self-righteous
stupor to empty nine codeine
bottles at once, even I began to
question his misdirected zeal.
That was a mistake. Before I
could complete a sentence he
grabbed my shirt and escorted
me to a table filled with drunken
druggies. On and on he raged
about shrunken livers, splintered
lungs and wasted bodies. He
concluded with a plea to go
straight and face a world filled
with "injustice, despair and
anxiety."
There were no buyers.

The debate tournament was in
full swing at Shriver Hall that
warm autumn weekend. As a
freshman and a newcomer to
Hopkins, I was pleased that the
Blue Jay debaters seemed to be
winning hands down. It had
surprised me, though, tha I was
the only spectator in the
enormous auditorium,. Is
anybody there? Does anybody
care? I asked myself.
"Don't feel downhearted,little
fellow. I care. I appreciate your
support here today," a
well-modulated voice addressed
me. I judged from the rhinestone
letters on his suit that my
comforter was none other than
Big Ed Brokans himself, author,
parliamentarian, orator, and
political adviser to student
governments. I was pleasantly
shocked that somehow so
important a personage would
take the time out to talk to a
humble freshman. I was further
surpised when Mr. Brokans'
opponents conceded him victory
before the debates even started.
, Such. was this man's reputation!
"I have won enough trophies
for Hopkins to fill all the steam
tunnels seven times over," he
explained to me over milk and
cookies at the Rathskellar."Why
do I bother, you may ask, when

you know we don't have room
anywhere for all of them and
they have to be melted down or
else thrown in the dumpster.
Well, I'll tell you. I don't do it
for the fame I do it because I
realize that I am the heir of a
great oral tradition.
Singlehandedly I have kept the
esoteric art of debate alive at this
school. When all around me
fuzzy -brained cretins are
polluting the air with "well,"
"Like," and the ineluctable "you
know," I remain a bastion of
articulate speech."
How to shaft
I knew right there and then
that I had found in Ed Brokans a
model worth emulating. Under
his guidance, I learned how to

put witnesses on the spot at
S.A.C. meetings, how to draw up
constitutions, how to tear apart
others' constitutions, how to run
a meeting, how to walk out of a
meeting somebody else is
running, and above all, how to
win by intimidation.
Who knows what further
heights I would have attained
with such a man as my teacher,
had not a tragic accident on C
level buried our distinguished
debate council president and
resident constitutionalist under
an avalanche of law books. His
passing, so painless and so poetic,
is our disability, thus our
opportunity—to nurture his
global legacy of healing
knowledge and the institutions
he built upon his rocklike belief
in man's power over man.

Rocky Mountain High?

The falling apart of a Bergen County youth
By SLUGGO MADISON
They showed us how to roll
joints in the tenth grade during a
two week respite from Phys. Ed.
Class entitled simply, "Health."
After attempting for several days
to depict the heartbreak and
failure of the "marijuana junkie"
Mr. Demske tossed his narcotic
manual in a handcar to hell and
said with a grin; "All right,
enough of that crap. Who wants
to get high?" Sure enough, after
a few hesitant moments of
scanning the classroom to see
who was going to make the
Plunge, all of the eighteen
students threw their right hand
into the air, much to the pleasure
of our instructor, who after this
liberation was familiarly referred
to as the good Dr. Demski or
Uncle Walt.
Well, for the remaining week

of Health Class we got stoned as
hell. Uncle Walt spoke about the
difference between Mexican and
Columbian weed, how to smuggle
black hashish from afghanistan
and why Top's rolling papers
afford a smoother smoke than
Zig-Zag's. He showed us how to
cut a quarter pound, roach a
joint and clean a clay pipe. It was
a tribute to the sophistication of
Suffolk County's youth that not
one of us was suckered into a five
dollar bag of catnip.
But my courtship with drugs
didn't end with the good doctor's
course. Every day we would cut
class, and cluster in the woods
behind the school, tokin' and
snortin' our brains out! And
while not everyone was dodging
the "intolerable reality" that
some hygiene teacher from
Bergen County, N.J. dreamed up,

it wasn't a flu epidemic that
emptied the case of Visine eye
drops that grocer Wilson kept
behind the counter.
Once I mastered the ins and
outs of dope smoking, I turned
to the "other poisons" that were
just begging to be consumed.
Beer and acid, whiskey and
Kools. And by my junior year I
was so versed in illegal substances
that Mr. Demske chose two
friends and I to represent our
class in the annual Trivia Bowl.
With the aid of a couple bottles
of Cold Duck and three bongs of
homegrown we took the contest
faster than you could say "John
Denver for a natural high!"
But now, after years of
chemically-induced evasion of
reality, a new element is coming
into play for the addled cowboys
of this world. One of my friends,

you see, his mind is breaking
down. He's been seen in
whirlwinds, uprooting pot plants,
overturning infirmary pill
cannisters and angrily crushing
beer cans. He goes blank at the
sight of an alkie, yelling
"drunken lout, always roaming
around, spitting and sputtering,
I'll settle his hash, you bet I
will!"
And so, my friend who has
been dubbed "Mr. Rocky
Mountain High" by some of my
less generous drugged cronies, is
running in circles with a pitiful
quioxtic gleam in his eyes,
chanting continuously "I will not
smoke pot, I will not smoke
pot." The nurses say that he'll
get over this obsession and that
it's just a phase that many Bergen
County youths are suffering
through right now. But when I

told the doctor that my friend's
case was indeed serious and not
just a case of the "Carrie Nation
delusions," he said to keep the
patient guarded, gag him tight
and maybe in a few weeks they'd
patch him up.
Alarmed by the sight of my
crusading friend last weekend,
attempting, in a self-righteous
stupor to empty nine codeine
bottles at once, even I began to
question his misdirected zeal.
That was a mistake. Before I
could complete a sentence he
grabbed my shirt and escorted
me to a table filled with drunken
druggies. On and on he raged
about shrunken livers, splintered
lungs and wasted bodies. He
concluded with a plea to go
straight and face a world filled
with "injustice, despair and
anxiety."
There were no buyers.
